member.name: T:Fundamentals.Sorting.BubbleSort
member.summary: Bubble sort, sometimes referred to as sinking sort, is a simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly steps through the list, compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order. The pass through the list is repeated until the list is sorted. The algorithm, which is a comparison sort, is named for the way smaller or larger elements "bubble" to the top of the list.

member.name: T:Fundamentals.Sorting.InsertionSort
member.summary: Insertion sort is a simple sorting algorithm that builds the final sorted array (or list) one item at a time. It is much less efficient on large lists than more advanced algorithms such as quicksort, heapsort, or merge sort.

member.name: T:Fundamentals.Sorting.ISort
member.summary: Exposes a method that sorts the elements in a one-dimensional array.

member.name: M:Fundamentals.Sorting.ISort.Sort``1(``0[])
member.summary: Sorts the elements in an entire using the generic interface implementation of each element of the Array.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of the array.
member.exception: One or more elements in array do not implement the generic interface.

member.name: T:Fundamentals.Sorting.MergeSort
member.summary: In computer science, merge sort (also commonly spelled mergesort) is an efficient, general-purpose, comparison-based sorting algorithm. Most implementations produce a stable sort, which means that the order of equal elements is the same in the input and output. Merge sort is a divide and conquer algorithm that was invented by John von Neumann in 1945. A detailed description and analysis of bottom-up mergesort appeared in a report by Goldstine and von Neumann as early as 1948.

member.name: T:Fundamentals.Sorting.SelectionSort
member.summary: Selection sort is an in-place comparison sorting algorithm. It has an O(n2) time complexity, which makes it inefficient on large lists, and generally performs worse than the similar insertion sort.
